title: Scientific Method and Investigation

vocab.definition: An educated guess about what will happen in an experiment
Something that can change in an experiment
Using your senses to gather information
What you learn from the results of an experiment
A brief statement that tells the main points of what you learned
Information collected during an experiment
The variable that is changed on purpose in an experiment
The variable that is measured or observed in an experiment
The group used for comparison that does not get the change
A visual way to show data, such as a line or bar graph
A chart that organizes data in rows and columns
A factor that is kept the same in all groups during an experiment
Something you keep the same so the test is fair
An investigation where only the independent variable changes and other factors are controlled
One complete run of an experiment
Repeating trials or having multiple samples to check reliability
A step-by-step plan for how to do the experiment
The supplies and tools used in an investigation
Descriptions using words or categories (no numbers)
Measurements using numbers and units
An unfair influence that can affect how an investigation is done or interpreted
How close a measurement is to the true value
How close repeated measurements are to each other
Facts and data that support a claim
An explanation or idea based on observations and prior knowledge
The group that receives the change being tested
How consistent results are when an investigation is repeated
How well an investigation measures what it is supposed to measure
The number of items or participants tested in an investigation
A data point that is very different from the others
A clear way to measure or observe a variable

teachingNotes: Guide students through designing and conducting simple experiments. Emphasize the importance of fair testing and controlling variables. Practice making predictions and drawing conclusions from data.

sample.question: What are the main steps of the scientific method?
expectedAny: ask a question, make a hypothesis, test, analyze data, conclude

sample.question: What is a variable?
expectedAny: anything that can be changed or measured

sample.question: Name one way to collect data.
What should you do if your results don't match your hypothesis?
expectedAny: change the procedure and test again

truefalse.question: A hypothesis must always be proven correct.
Scientists use data to support conclusions.
Changing many variables at once makes a fair test.
Observations can be made with tools and senses.
A conclusion is a guess before the experiment.

multiplechoice.question: What should you do first when starting a scientific investigation?
Why use a control in an experiment?
Which graph is best for change over time?

fillintheblank.question: An educated guess about what will happen in an experiment is called a ________.
The thing you change in an experiment is the ________ variable.
The thing you measure is the ________ variable.
Information collected during an experiment is called ________.
A fair test changes only ________ variable at a time.
A written summary of what you learned is the ________.

shortanswer.question: Why is it important to change only one variable at a time in an experiment?
expectedAny: isolate the effect of the independent variable

shortanswer.question: How can graphs help you understand data?
Give an example of a testable hypothesis.
expectedAny: If plants get more light, then they grow taller
If we add fertilizer, then plants grow faster
If temperature rises, then ice melts
If water is warmer, then sugar dissolves faster
If we increase sunlight, then plant height increases

shortanswer.question: Why should scientists share methods and results?
What should you do if results are unexpected?
What is the purpose of a control group?
expectedAny: to see the effect of the independent variable

shortanswer.question: How do you choose which graph to use?
expectedAny: pie for parts of a whole
line shows change over time; bar compares groups
